conclusion: Shadows are formed when an object blocks the light from the light source.
The size and position of the shadow depend on the relative positions of the light source, the object, and the surface where the shadow is cast.
In the initial setup, the light source is positioned such that it casts shadows A, B, C, and D as shown in the image.
When the light source moves backward, the angle at which the light rays hit the objects changes.
This change in angle affects both the size and the position of the shadows.
As the light source moves backward, the angle of the light rays becomes more parallel to the surface, resulting in the shadows becoming smaller.
When the light source moves backward, the shadows will shift closer to the objects.
Shadow A will become smaller and move closer to the cup.
Shadow B will become smaller and move closer to the avocado.
Shadow C will become smaller and move closer to the object labeled C.
Shadow D will become smaller and move closer to the egg carton.
When the light source moves backward, the shadows A, B, C, and D will become smaller and will shift closer to their respective objects.
